Figure 1 Fig. 2 SEM and EDS mappings of (a, d, g) MC, (b, e, h) PbO(1.0)-MC and (c, f, i) PbCl2(1.0)-MC catalysts. Figure 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of (a) PbO(x)-MC and (b) PbCl2(y)-MC catalysts. Figure 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of MC, PbO(1.0)-MC and PbCl2(1.0)-MC catalysts. Peak I, Peak II and Peak III respectively represented weak, medium and strong acid sites; the corresponding value attached was its peak area integration. Figure 6 Fig. 7 In-situ DRIFTS of 1000 ppm NH3 adsorption + 11 vol.% O2 adsorption with 50 mL/min flow rate at 25 ∼ 300 °C with an interval of 25 °C on (a) MC, (b) PbO(1.0)-MC and (c) PbCl2(1.0)-MC catalysts. (d) NH3 adsorption+ 11 vol.% O2 adsorption for 1 h at 225 °C over the three catalysts. Figure 7 Fig. 8 In-situ DRIFTS of NO+O2 reacted with pre-adsorbed NH3 at 225 °C on (a) MC, (b) PbO(1.0)-Mc and (c) PbCl2(1.0)-MC catalysts. In situ DRIFTS of NH3 reacted with pre-adsorbed NO+O2 at 225 °C on (d) MC, (e) PbO(1.0)-Mc and (f) PbCl2(1.0)-MC catalysts. Figure 8 Fig. 9 Temperature-Gibbs free energy curve (Ellingham Diagrams) for the reaction between M x Oy(PbCl2) and NH3 Figure 9 Fig. 10 Schematic diagram of PbCl2 and PbO poisoning mechanisms over MC catalysts. In this work, the poisoning behaviors of PbO and PbCl2 on MC catalyst were explored, and their deactivation mechanisms were also clarified. Results indicated that PbCl2 presented more severe poisonousness than PbO. The addition of PbO obstructed favorable electron conversions between Mn and Ce atoms, consuming more oxygen vacancies and active oxygen species, consequently hindering the redox cycle. Apart from Pb poisoning effect, newly generated HCl over PbCl2-doped catalyst could preferentially adsorb on CeO2 to form inactive Cl− bonds and NH4Cl deposition, further limiting the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and reducing surface acid sites. Therefore, MC catalyst was deactivated more severely by the double poisoning cycles (Pb + HCl). This work paves a way for the development of high-performance Pb-tolerant low-temperature SCR catalyst, as well as Pb-deactivated catalyst regeneration technology. Graphical Abstract : Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MnO x -CeO2 catalyst Ti-bearing blast furnace slag Deactivation mechanism PbO PbCl2 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) as an effective strategy for alleviating NO x emission has been widely used in stationary and mobile sources in recent years. Commercial V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 SCR catalyst is the most widely employed due to its excellent properties [1–5]. However, this catalyst is not applicable for low-temperature flue gas denitration (usually below 250 °C) in metallurgy, cement, glass and other non-electric industries [6–9]. Consequently, more attention has been paid to develop the outstanding-efficiency low-temperature SCR catalysts. Among these developed catalysts, excellent activity has been discovered for a novel MnO x -CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag low-temperature SCR catalyst in our previous study. The obtained Ti-Si-Al compound from Ti-bearing blast furnace slag was regarded as catalyst support, which could realize waste utilization [10–12]. As known, sintering flue gas from iron-steel industries is one of the NO x pollution sources with high concentrations of oxygen (10 ∼ 15 vol%), fly ash, water, sulfur oxides, acid gas, alkali/alkaline-earth metals and heavy metals etc. Low temperature NH3-SCR technology has also been used in this field. Generally, most sintering plants have firstly applied dust removal system and flue gas desulfurization (FGD) system for pollutants treatment (e.g., high dust, SO x , alkali and heavy metals), followed by SCR unit to further control NO x emission. Heavy metals contents in the sintering mixture followed a descending order of Pb > Cr > Cd [13]. In flue gas from sintering machines with wet FGD, the original concentrations of heavy metals (Hg, Zn, As, and Pb, etc.) were up to 350.4 μg/m3, and Pb content accounted for the highest proportion of 93.3% [14]. Pb mainly existed in solid and liquid phases and its compounds included PbCl2 and PbO, etc. Although nearly 65% of total heavy metals can be removed after FGD purification [14], the remaining still showed a poisonous threat to catalytic service lifetime in subsequent SCR process. Therefore, clarifying catalyst deactivation reasons, especially Pb species, was significant for prolonging catalyst life and thus reducing the SCR flue gas denitrification costs. Researchers have performed the studies concerning Pb poisoning effect on some SCR catalysts. Jiang et al. claimed that PbO could react with Mo species to generate PbMoO4, thereby markedly declined catalyst surface acidity and reducibility [15]. They also proposed PbCl2-poisoned mechanism over V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, namely, inactive bonds between PbCl2 and vanadia species severely damaged SCR activity [16]. Besides, the effects of PbO and PbCl2 over CeO2-TiO2 catalyst were compared, finding that the former caused more serious catalyst deactivation [17]. Interestingly, when similar work was conducted on V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, opposite result was seen that PbCl2 presented more severe poisoning influence [16,18]. The phenomenon indicated that various catalysts were extremely susceptible to different Pb species, and the deactivated reasons may be also different. Notes that the above studies have focused on medium-high temperature (300 ∼ 500 °C) catalyst deactivation by Pb species in the flue gas from MSW incineration plants and other power plants, whereas the relevant research on low temperature catalysts (usually below 250 °C) in sintering plants has never been extensively investigated. Though PbO poisoning effect over low temperature Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst has been reported, the deactivation mechanism was not further elucidated [19]. Furthermore, to our best knowledge, the comparison of PbO and PbCl2 effects over MnO x -CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst has hardly been studied until our present work. Therefore, it is necessary to thoroughly study the difference of PbO/PbCl2-deactivation mechanisms over this novel catalyst in sintering flue gas denitration process. In this work, the most common Pb pollutants (PbO and PbCl2) were separately doped to MnO x -CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag low-temperature SCR catalyst. A series of characterization methods (BET, XRD, SEM, XPS, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, in-situ DRIFT) were employed to illustrate the interactions between catalysts and poisons through the variations of surface acidity, redox properties, gas adsorption behaviors, active sites, and surface elements concentrations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The PbO/PbCl2-poisoned catalysts were prepared by firstly impregnating MnO x -CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst (denoted as MC, Mn/Ce molar ratio = 4:1) into Pb(NO3)2/PbCl2 solutions, respectively. The mixture was then heated in water bath at 80 °C with a continuous stirring to form pastes. Later the pastes were dried at 80 °C for 24 h, followed by calcination at 500 °C for 6 h. The acquired samples were termed PbO(x)-MC and PbCl2(y)-MC (x and y represented Pb/Mn molar ratio of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1.0). To avoid the influence of variable factors, MC catalyst was calcined at 500 °C for 6 h again. The above obtained catalysts were ground into less than 200 meshes for properties characterization and crushed into 40 ∼ 60 meshes for activity test. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the samples were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The microstructures and elements distribution were studied by Scanning Electron Micrograph (SEM, Zeiss Merlin Compact). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) was operated by Rigaku D/max-2500/PC diffractometer with the scanning range of 10o to 90o. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained with Al Kα X-ray (hv = 1486.6 eV) radiation at 150 W from Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi. H2-TPR measurement was performed on an automatic chemical adsorption instrument (CHEMBET PULSAR TPR) of QUANTACHROME INSTRUMENTS. Each catalyst (90 mg) was pretreated using He (50 ml/min) for 0.5 h at 300 °C and then cooled to 30 °C. Each sample was later heated to 700 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of hydrogen gas to record H2 TPR signal. NH3-TPD was conducted in a quartz reactor using 100 mg sample. After same pretreatment as H2-TPR, each sample was exposed to a 500 ppm NH3 flow for 1.5 h at 30 °C. Finally, it was heated to 600 °C at constant heating rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of 50 ml/min He. Nicolet iS50 spectrometer was used to record Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) and investigate the surface functional groups of catalysts in the range of 4000 ∼ 400 cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic performance Activity measurement was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor (0.4 g samples). The feed gas mixture contained 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 11% O2, and N2 as the balance gas; the total flow rate was 200 mL/min, and GHSV ≈ 30000 mL/g·h. The outlet NO and N2O concentrations was respectively detected by a flue gas analyzer (Thermo Scientific, Antaris IGS) and a N2O detector (China, SinGoAn SGA-500B-N2O). NO conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated according to the following formulas (Eqs. (1) and (2)): (1) NO conversion ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] out + [ N O 2 ] out [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in ) × 100 % where [NO]in and [NO]out represented the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO; [NO2]out and [N2O]out stand for the outlet concentrations of NO2 and N2O, respectively. 2.4 Thermodynamic calculation High oxidation state oxides were reduced step by step in NH3-SCR process. In order to estimate oxidative capacity of each kind of M x Oy (or PbCl2), it was assumed that M x Oy were reduced to metals [20]. As shown in Eqs. (3 ~ 7), the redox reactions that happened between each kind of M x Oy (or PbCl2) and NH3 were discussed in a thermodynamic way. The Gibbs free energy (△G) of each reaction during 100∼500 °C was respectively calculated by the FactSage Software. (3) 3 Mn O 2 + 4 N H 3 → 3 Mn + 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O (4) M n 2 O 3 + 2 N H 3 → 2 Mn + 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O (5) 3 Ce O 2 + 4 N H 3 → 3 Ce + 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O (6) 3 PbO + 2 N H 3 → 3 Pb + N 2 + 3 H 2 O (7) 3 PbC l 2 + 2 N H 3 → 3 Pb + N 2 + 6 HCl 3 Result and Discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR performance MC catalyst was selected for subsequent experiments. Fig. 1 (a) showed its NO conversion and N2 selectivity within 75 ∼ 300°C under a GHSV of 30000 mL/g·h. This catalyst exhibited higher activity with temperature rising (NO conversion yielded 88.6% at 300 °C), while more than 90% N2 selectivity was maintained below 225 °C. Fig. 1(b) compared the effect of two poisons on catalyst SCR performance at 225 °C. After different contents of PbO or PbCl2 doped, N2 selectivity slightly changed but NO conversion seriously declined. PbCl2(y)-MC presented more serious deactivation than PbO(x)-MC when Pb/Mn molar ratio was same. It indicated that the existence of Cl atoms could further deactivate MC catalyst. In addition, with Pb/Mn molar ratio rising from 0.1 to 1.0, activity variations of both Pb-doped catalysts during 75 ∼ 300 °C were also measured (Fig. 1(c) and (d)). At higher temperatures (175 °C ∼ 300 °C), NO conversion of both Pb-poisoned catalysts gradually declined with Pb/Mn molar ratio, and the gap markedly widened. It meant that Pb content was a crucial factor for MC catalyst poisoning. At lower temperatures (75 °C ∼ 175 °C), there was a small difference between NO conversion of almost all poisoned catalysts (less than 20%). Specially, activity of PbO(0.1)-MC was litter higher than that of MC below 175 °C. Trace PbO doping increased BET surface area of MC catalyst, and thus might promote SCR reaction slightly. 3.2 Structure Properties According to MC catalyst deactivation phenomenon, N2 physisorption was measured to determine whether Pb species damaged its surface structure. From BET data listed in Table 1 , trace amounts of PbO/PbCl2 (Pb/Mn = 0.1) increased the BET surface area of MC catalyst. Pb element (1.19 Å) has a similar cationic radius to Ce element (1.03 Å). When Pb species was introduced to this catalyst, it could occupy part of lattice locations of cerium oxides, thus decreasing crystal sizes and increasing surface area [21–23]. However, excessive Pb dopant decreased BET surface area and pore volume. The higher Pb/Mn ratio (>0.2), the smaller BET surface area and pore volume. This was because high amount of PbO/PbCl2 could induce catalyst micropores blocking and metal oxides agglomeration [24,25]. By comparison, the surface area and pore volume of PbCl2(>0.2)-MC declined more remarkably than that of PbO(>0.2)-MC under the same Pb/Mn molar ratio (specially x = y = 1.0). The phenomenon indicated that PbCl2 caused more severe destruction on catalyst surface, which probably caused by the chlorination of catalytic active components (interaction with Cl atoms). Besides, the catalyst pore diameter was slightly affected by two Pb poisons. SEM and EDS mappings were conducted to obtain the microstructures and main elements dispersion on MC and Pb-poisoned catalysts surfaces. As shown in Fig. 2 , catalyst support was composed of many irregular blocks, mainly containing elements of Si, Ti, Al, etc. MC catalyst was relatively smooth, and active components Ce and Mn were uniformly dispersed (Fig. 2(a), (d) and (g)). When Pb poisons were introduced, a large number of debris and components agglomeration appeared. Pb-doped catalyst showed much rougher surface than MC catalyst (Fig. 2(b), (c), (e) and (f)). Based on the EDS mappings (Fig. 2(g), (h) and (i)), it could be further discovered that Pb species partly decreased Mn and Ce dispersion, while Pb atoms highly covered catalyst surface. The phenomenon suggested that PbO and PbCl2 were successfully introduced to MC catalyst during the preparation process, which resulted in manganese and cerium oxides agglomeration as well as BET surface area decrease. 3.3 XRD and XPS analysis XRD characterization was carried out to study the crystal structure of MC, PbO-MC and PbCl2-MC catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 3 , a peak of MC sample attributed to amorphous SiO2 (15 ∼ 35o) appeared, coupled with a small shoulder (33.1o) ascribed to CeO2 [26]. The curve suggested that most manganese and cerium oxides were amorphous or/and highly dispersed on catalyst surface, which was beneficial to acid sites formation and activity improvement. From Fig. 3(a), rare amount of PbO had negligible effect on phase structure of MC catalyst, whereas its high loading (Pb/Mn >0.2) resulted in SiO2 peak shifting from ∼23.6 to ∼28.4 o. This may be due to strong interaction between PbO and Ti-Si-Al composite support. High PbO dopant would induce macroscopic residual stress in MC catalyst unit cells, thereby further leading to SiO2 lattice distortion, contraction and peak shift. Different from PbO, PbCl2 didn't cause diffraction peak shift but it was easily converted into crystalline phases (Pb/Mn molar ratio >0.5). In particular, a large quantity of PbCl2 crystals were generated on PbCl2(1.0)-MC, which was the main reason for significant decrease in BET surface area (Table 1). As a result, the SCR reaction sites for gas adsorption declined. From above analysis, PbO/PbCl2(1.0)-MC showed the worst physical properties. Therefore, they were selected to compare with MC catalyst in terms of element valence and relative proportion on the surface. Fig. 4 (a-d) presented different XPS spectra of Pb 4f, Mn 2p, Ce 3d and O 1s, respectively; Table 2 showed the corresponding elements proportions. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the peaks at 138.3 eV and 143.2 eV represented Pb 4f 7/2 and Pb 4f 5/2 characters for Pb-deactivated catalysts, implying that Pb2+ existed on the catalyst surface. According to the standard Pb 4f spectra in XPS handbook (Pb 4f 7/2 at 137.5 eV, Pb 4f 5/2 at 142.4 eV) [27], Pb character peaks of the samples shifted towards higher BE values. There was a strong electronic interaction between Pb atoms and catalyst components, which decreased the density of Pb electron clouds and induced electron migration around Pb atoms [19]. Mn 2p spectrum made up of a spin-orbit doublet with Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 peaks at 637 ∼ 659 eV (Fig. 4(b)). The asymmetric Mn 2p3/2 spectra could be fitted into three peaks at 641.5 ∼ 642.0 eV, 642.8 ∼ 644.9 eV and 646.1 ∼ 647.3 eV, corresponding to Mn3+, Mn4+ and Mn-nitrate, respectively [19,28]. MC catalyst exhibited the highest Mn4+ content (43.9%) and smallest Mn-nitrate amount (7.2%). After PbO was introduced to this catalyst, Mn4+ and Mn-nitrate concentrations obviously changed to 33.5% and 21.7%. The relative proportions variations demonstrated that PbO species could transform manganese oxidation states by restraining electron transfer around Mn atoms. It was widely accepted that Mn4+ species was beneficial to NO removal and redox capacity, as well as performed promotion to the oxidation of NO to NO2 [29,30]. Therefore, in this regards, the decreasing Mn4+ concentration of PbO(1.0)-MC was one of the key reasons for its poor activity. Besides, PbCl2 showed similar poisoning effect on MnO x species, but PbCl2(1.0)-MC yielded a bit higher Mn4+ content (37.5%). It suggested that the poisoning effects of PbO and PbCl2 on MnO x were not exactly equal, and the former may be a litter more serious. Namely, PbO dopant decreased high-valent manganese oxides by hindering electron conversions around Mn atoms to a greater extent. The result might be directly related to a larger increase in Mn-nitrate contents over PbO(1.0)-MC catalyst, which also can be observed in other literatures [19]. Fig. 4(c) displayed the XPS spectra of Ce 3d, which were the combination of Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 spectra. It could be divided into eight overlapped peaks with U1, V1 assigning to Ce3+ species, while the others belonging to Ce4+ species [5,6]. Ce3+ species could create charge imbalance, form oxygen vacancies and unsaturated chemical bonds on catalysts surface, which was conducive to NH3-SCR process [19]. In this work, Ce 3d peak intensity of MC catalyst obviously weakened after Pb species added, and Ce3+ proportion followed a sequence of MC>PbO(1.0)-MC>PbCl2(1.0)-MC (agreed with Fig. 1). This was because Pb2+ could partly occupy oxygen vacancies and further prevent Ce4+ from obtaining electrons to produce Ce3+ (VO · + Ce4+ → Ce3+ + VO). From Table 2, the amount of Ce3+ on PbCl2(1.0)-MC (21.3%) was lower than that of PbO(1.0)-MC (25.5%), indicating Cl atoms probably played an inhibitive role in active cerium oxides. Previously, Wang et al. discovered that Cl atoms showed a poisoning effect on MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalyst by preferentially anchoring on the uncoordinated position of Ce instead of Mn atoms [31]. Similarly, we can infer that apart from Pb, Cl atoms also obstructed the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ on MC catalyst, and thus the synergistic effect of Pb and Cl damaged CeO2 species more seriously. As presented in Fig. 4(d), O 1s curve could be fitted into two peaks, lattice oxygen (Oβ, 530.0 eV) and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα, 532.0 eV) [32,33]. As reported, the latter was the most active oxygen species that played a crucial role in SCR reaction due to its higher mobility on catalyst surface than inactive oxygen [34,35]. Herein, the Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio on PbO(1.0)-MC modestly dropped but oxygen intensity visibly decreased, suggesting that PbO declined mobile oxygen amounts on catalyst surface. For PbCl2(1.0)-MC catalyst, Oα and Oβ concentrations dramatically changed in comparison with MC catalyst (Table 2). PbCl2 dopant significantly consumed surface chemisorbed oxygen and probably interacted with the catalyst to generate complex compounds. From Fig. 4(b) and (c), the peaks intensity of Mn and Ce elements over Pb-poisoned samples obviously weakened, indicating that Pb species decreased active components Mn and Ce on catalyst surface. Therefore, conclusion could be drawn that Pb poisons would interact with MnO x and CeO2 species to form chemical compounds, decreasing oxygen mobility ability and further slowing down SCR reaction. Particularly, Cl atoms might involve in the new bonds formation and preferentially destroy active cerium oxide, and thus PbCl2 presented a more serious deactivation threat to MC catalyst. 3.4 Redox capacity and surface acidity Catalyst reducibility is considered as one of the most crucial property of SCR catalyst. Therefore, influences of PbO and PbCl2 on this property were explored by H2-TPR (Fig. 5 ). For fresh catalyst profile, the onset reduction temperature (ORT) was ∼ 97 °C, and manganese oxides reduction started at 148 °C (MnO2 → Mn2O3). A broad overlapped reduction peak then appeared (centered at 491 °C), primarily including manganese (Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 → MnO) and cerium oxides (CeO2→Ce2O3) reduction [36,37]. The H2 consumption above 600 °C could be ascribed to functional groups reduction of Ti-Si-Al support [38]. With PbO species doped, the catalyst ORT shifted to ∼ 300 °C, and the peaks attributing to MnO x (451 °C) and CeO2 (530 °C) reduction weakened. According to XPS result, this was because Pb atoms strongly boned with part of manganese and cerium oxides, thereby restraining electron exchange around Mn and Ce atoms. Interestingly, the reduction peak intensity at 599 °C on PbO(1.0)-MC catalyst was much stronger than others. As mentioned in XRD result, PbO could induce SiO2 lattice distortion and contraction, which probably changed the Ti-Si-Al carrier structure and further activated its functional groups. For PbCl2(1.0)-MC, the ORT shifted to higher temperature (∼ 340 °C), indicating that PbCl2 showed more serious impact on the redox capacity of MC catalyst. An obvious reduction peak (487 °C) then appeared, but the peak attributing to CeO2 reduction completely diminished. The phenomenon was lined in XPS inference. Mn4+ concentration on PbCl2(0.1)-MC was slightly higher than that of PbO(0.1)-MC, thereby redox ability of manganese oxides was relatively active. However, Cl atoms from PbCl2 preferentially interacted with cerium oxides and formed chemical bonds, which consequently obstructed CeO2 reduction more severely. NH3-TPD technique was conducted to analyze the surface acidity and NH3 adsorption ability. As shown in Fig. 6 , NH3-TPD profiles could be divided into three regions: the range below 260 °C, 260 ∼ 390 °C and 390 ∼ 600 °C, respectively ascribing to NH3 desorption from weak, medium and strong acid sites [35,39]. The peaks below 390°C were related to the Brønsted acid sites, while other peaks at 390 ∼ 600°C was originated from the Lewis acid sites [40]. When Pb poisons were added to MC catalyst, the peaks intensity assigning to Brønsted acid sites considerably weakened, while those of Lewis acid sites decreased slightly. PbO and PbCl2 primarily destroyed the Brønsted acid sites of MnO x and CeO2, which was an important reason for catalyst deactivation [17,19]. Furthermore, the loss of acid sites on PbCl2(1.0)-MC was greater than that of PbO(1.0)-MC based on the peaks integration. High content of Ce3+ was helpful to the formation of Brønsted acid sites for NH3 adsorption [41]. From XPS result, synergistic effects of Pb and Cl atoms obstructed redox cycle of Mn3+ + Ce4+ ↔ Mn4+ + Ce3+ more seriously than that of single Pb. Therefore, lower Ce3+ concentration was detected on PbCl2-poisoned catalyst, which was not favorable to form Brønsted acid sites on its surface. 3.5 In-situ DRIFT spectra 3.5.1 NH3 adsorption The NH3-DRIFTS in the range of 25 ∼ 300 °C were investigated to study acidity difference on the three catalysts (Fig. 7 ). As shown in Fig. 7(a), MC catalyst surface was mainly covered by a couple of NH3 species after NH3 exposure for 1 h. The bands at 1606 cm−1 and 1262 cm−1 were attributed to asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of N-H bonds in coordinated NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites; the bands at 3032 ∼ 3377 cm−1 were associated with N-H stretching modes of coordinated NH3; the bands at 1731 cm−1 and 1467 cm−1 were attributed to symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites [9,42,43]. MC catalyst showed large quantity of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites at low temperature, whereas these acid sites obviously decreased with temperature rising. It suggested that the catalytic thermal stability definitely declined at higher temperature, thus the NH3 adsorption capacity of catalyst were accordingly limited. From Fig. 7(b) and (c), similar DRIFT spectra appeared on the Pb-deactivated catalysts after NH3 adsorption for 1 h (coordinated NH3: 3377 ∼ 3032 cm−1, 1608 ∼ 1612 cm−1 and 1255 cm−1; ionic NH4 +: 1731 cm−1 and 1458 cm−1). Nonetheless, compared with MC counterpart, peaks intensity of the poisoned-catalysts obviously decreased, and they showed much worse thermal stability at higher temperature. In particular, the variations of acid sites on the catalysts were compared at 225 °C (Fig. 7(d)). Two poisons showed restrictive effect on NH3 adsorption for Lewis and Brønsted acid sites (especially latter), and PbCl2 played a more severe inhibition role. The result was agreed well with NH3-TPD analysis, namely, Pb atoms intensively interacted with MnO x and CeO 2 , thus damaging many surface acid sites. Moreover, Cl atoms further deactivated Brønsted acid sites, thereby causing more serious catalyst deactivation. 3.5.2 Reaction between NOx and pre-adsorbed NH3 species The in-situ DRIFTS reaction between pre-adsorbed NH3 and NO + O2 at 225 °C was conducted to investigate NH3-SCR mechanism and NH3 species reactivity. From Fig. 8 (a), When NH3 was firstly imported, MC catalyst surface was mainly covered by ionic NH4 + (1437 cm−1) and coordinated NH3 (3278 cm−1 ∼ 3190 cm−1 and 1247 cm−1) [9,42]. After the introduction of NO + O2, all NH3 adsorption bands completely diminished within 15 min, while none of NO x species appeared during the whole process. The phenomenon indicated that NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites and coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites were highly active, which could quickly participate in SCR reaction with gaseous NO/NO x . The DRIFT spectra of PbO(1.0)-MC catalyst were also recorded under the same condition(Fig. 8(b)). Compared with MC sample, its intensity of NH3 adsorption peaks enormously weakened after NH3 imported. PbO greatly hindered NH3 adsorption on catalyst surface. When NO + O2 was then introduced into the IR cell, the peaks slowly weakened and finally disappeared until 30 min. By comparison, SCR reaction time of this poisoned catalyst was twice that of MC catalyst (15 min). This meant that PbO restricted the reactivity of NH3(a) species, making it difficult to participate in NO reduction. Even more seriously, the smallest NH3 adsorption peaks over PbCl2(1.0)-MC catalyst occurred under the same condition. PbCl2 limited NH3 adsorption and activation more severely. 3.5.3 Reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NOx species The reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO x species on the catalysts were carried out at 225 °C and the in-situ DRIFT spectra were presented in Fig. 8. From Fig. 8(d), none of NO x adsorption species were generated on catalyst surface when NO+O2 was pretreated. After NH3 introduction for 10 min, a peak (ionic NH4 +: 1473 cm−1) appeared and its intensity strengthened with time; other peaks (coordinated NH3: 3278 cm−1, 1255 cm−1) also gradually appeared [9,42]. The phenomenon suggested that NH3 gas could preferentially adsorb on MC catalyst in the form of either NH4 + species or coordinated NH3, whereas gaseous NO/NO x cannot transform into adsorbed state but directly reacted with above NH3(a) species. Herein, Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism was suitable to the NH3-SCR reaction of MC catalyst. From Fig. 8(e) and (f), similar DRIFT spectra can be seen over Pb-deactivated catalysts under the same treatment. PbO and PbCl2 didn't change the E-R mechanism of MC catalyst. However, two poisons showed different negative effects on the denitration process. In the case of PbO(1.0)-MC (Fig. 8(e)), a weak peak at 1435 cm−1 did not occur until NH3 exposure for 20 min, which was 10 min later than that of MC catalyst. The peak intensity of poisoned-catalyst also significantly weakened. These could verify above analysis that PbO presented an inhibition on NH3 adsorption. For PbCl2-MC catalyst (Fig. 8(f)), a similar peak at 1414 cm−1 appeared much later (30 min), accompanying with lower intensity, which demonstrated more severe destruction of acid sites after PbCl2 introduced (fitted with 3.5.2 section). 3.6 Thermodynamics analysis of reactions between M x O y /PbCl2 and NH3 It was widely accepted that the first step in SCR was an oxidative abstraction of the hydrogen from adsorbed NH3 [44] Metal oxides can provide active sites and electrons for capturing and oxidizing NH3, which was beneficial to SCR activity improvement. The possible redox reactions that happened between metal oxides (M x Oy/PbCl2) and NH3 were presented in a thermodynamic way. The △G value of each reaction (Eqs. 3∼7) during 100∼500 °C was calculated (Table 3 ), and variation of straight slope of the temperature-Gibbs free energy curve (Ellingham Diagrams) was presented (Fig. 9 ). Generally, reaction would take place easily when the △G was negative (△G < 0); while if the△G was positive (△G > 0), reaction might happen at higher temperature or under other specific condition (e.g., catalytic atmosphere). Herein, △G value generally followed an increasing sequence of △G(PbO) < △G(MnO2) < G(Mn2O3) < △G(PbCl2) < △G(CeO2) during 100 °C∼500 °C. △G(MnO2) value was negative above 200 °C, indicating that MnO2 was effective for the oxidative abstraction of hydrogen from adsorbed NH3. However, CeO2 showed the opposite result and △G(CeO2) value was particularly positive. It might be on account of neglecting kinetics or simplifying assumptions during the thermodynamic calculations [20]. Additionally, △G(PbO) was more negative during 100 °C∼500 °C in comparison with others. It implied that PbO was easier to participate in NH3-SCR reaction by promoting NH3 oxidation, and thus significantly influenced MnO x -CeO2 redox cycle over MC catalyst. In contrast, the positive △G(PbCl2) value indicated that PbCl2 can't involve in the adsorption and oxidation of NH3 spontaneously (consistent with section 3.5.analysis). Instead, this poison probably deactivated MC catalyst by damaging active MnO x -CeO2 sites. 3.7 The poisoning mechanisms of PbO and PbCl2 over MC catalyst According to above analysis, MC catalyst exhibited excellent SCR performance mainly resulting from surface acid sites, strong reducibility and high surface concentrations of Ce3+, Mn4+, chemisorbed oxygen, whereas it could be deactivated by PbO and PbCl2 to different extents. In our previous literatures [28,45,46], the deactivation mechanisms of alkali and heavy metals (K, Hg, Zn etc.) over MnO x or V2O5-based catalysts were well clarified. We found that poisons seriously deactivated catalyst by preferentially attacking Brønsted (V-O/Mn-O bonds) and Lewis acid sites (V=O/Mn=O bonds). Similarly, combined with Pb binding features [47], the possible PbO and PbCl2 poisoning mechanisms over MC catalyst were proposed in Fig. 10 . In case of PbO-MC catalysts, Pb2+ was more likely to react with both Brønsted acid sites (M-OH, M=Ce, Mn) and Lewis acid sites (M=O) to respectively form -M-O-Pb-O-M- and -M-O···Pb bonds, and simultaneously generated H2O (Eqs. (a)’ and (b)’). These newly inactive chemical bonds consumed surface chemisorbed oxygen and restrained redox cycle of MnO x and CeO2 (H2-TPR result), while Pb2+ hindered NH3 adsorption and activation by destructing catalyst acid sites (NH3-TPD result). As a result, the SCR performance of PbO-doped catalyst markedly declined. For PbCl2-MC catalysts, PbCl2 damaged Brønsted acid sites (M-OH, M=Ce, Mn) and Lewis acid sites (M=O) by respectively forming -M-O-Pb-O-M- or -M-O-Pb-Cl bonds. Inactive Cl− bonds generally can't revitalize adsorbed ammonia [28], and even further deactivated Mn-O-Ce sites. Besides, by-product HCl might be produced during this process (Eqs. (a) and (b)), which was similar to other literatures [16]. HCl could preferentially interact with Ce species to further deactivate MC catalyst (XPS result). To be precise, HCl could firstly adsorb on Lewis acid sites (Ce=O) to form inactive -Cl-Ce-OH bonds ((Eq. (c)), and then the new Cl− bonds could proceed to react with PbCl2 to form Cl-Ce-O-Pb-O-Ce- and HCl ((Eq. (d)). Therefore, the double poisoning cycles (Pb + HCl) can be built up ((Eqs. (a) ∼ (e)). It was worth noting that part of HCl could directly react with NH3 to form NH4Cl deposition on catalyst surface, thus reduced NH3 amount of participating in SCR reaction [31]. In brief, PbCl2 showed more severe deactivation over MC catalyst than PbO. Besides the poisonous effect of Pb2+, Cl− also played a key role. On the one hand, Pb2+ could interact with MnO x and CeO2 to form chemical bonds, thereby restricted catalyst redox ability, NH3 adsorption and activation. On the other hand, new Cl- bonds and by-product HCl was generated during PbCl2 poisoning process. The former further deactivated Mn-O-Ce sites while the latter damaged CeO2 and promote NH4Cl deposition formation, which obstructed the SCR reaction more significantly. 3.8 Possible approaches to mitigate Pb poisoning of MC catalyst According to above analysis, Pb dopant seriously damaged catalytic active components, resulting in a marked decrease in Mn4+, Ce3+ and Oα concentrations, surface acidity and redox capacity of MC catalyst. Some possible ways to prolong Pb-poisoned catalyst lifespan were proposed below. (1) Some of metal oxides (Fe2O3, Co2O3, CuO and NiO etc.) were high reactivity, redox performance and a large number of acid sites. Regarding them as modifying agents was expected to mitigate the Pb poisoning effect on MC catalyst. The main ideas of enhancing catalyst Pb-resistance were that (a) ensure sufficient surface acidic sites and improve redox properties; (b) transfer attack sites of the poisons and simultaneously protect previous active sites. (2) Catalyst regeneration has been considered as a feasible approach for prolonging poisoned-catalyst lifespan. The possible methods were as followed: (a) wash Pb-deactivated catalysts with acid solution (dilute sulfuric acid, citric acid, acetic acid, etc.), water or alkaline solution (sodium hydroxide, ammonium hydroxide, etc.) to remove poisons or introduce new active sites; (b) treat Pb-poisoned catalysts at high temperature to break the stabilities of Pb species and then reduce the poisoning effect; (c) develop catalytic special structures (e.g., core-shell, lamellar and 3D layer structures) to insulate the poisons from outside and thus protect the active components. 4 Conclusion The poisoning effects of PbO and PbCl2 on SCR performance of MC catalyst were compared in this study via a series of characterization methods. Results indicated that this catalyst presented worse SCR activity in the presence of PbCl2 under the influence of reaction temperature and Pb doping content. The key findings were as follows: (1) Pb doping content was a major reason for MC catalyst deactivation. The poisoning degree gradually increased with Pb/Mn molar ratio (0.1 ∼ 1.0). PbCl2 presented more serious poisonousness on catalyst activity than PbO under the same condition. (2) For PbO-poisoned catalyst, Pb2+ could interact with CeO2 and MnO x to form inactive bonds. This reaction could obstruct favorable electron conversions around Mn and Ce atoms, consume more oxygen vacancies and active oxygen species, and consequently hinder the redox cycle. Also, active acid sites (CeO2 and MnO x ) were damaged, thereby NH3 adsorption capacity and NH3 species reactivity were restrained. (3) PbCl2 was easier to form crystalline phases, causing smaller BET surface area of MC catalyst. Apart from above similar effect of Pb2+, newly formed HCl could also deactivate MC catalyst. HCl would preferentially adsorb on CeO2 species to form inactive Cl− bonds and NH4Cl deposition, thereby further hindered the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and reduced surface acid sites. As a result, the double poisoning cycles (Pb + HCl) deactivated MC catalyst more severely. (4) Above results can act as guidance for solving Pb poisoning problem of low-temperature SCR catalyst. (a) Regarding extra metal oxides as a modifying agent to optimize catalytic surface acidity and redox properties, (b) exploring catalyst regeneration technology to remove Pb poison and enhance surface acid sites, might be the ways to prolong Pb-poisoned catalyst lifespan. coredata.dc:description: Pb poisoning of MnO x -CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag SCR catalyst (MC) at low temperature is a tough challenge for NO x emission control in sintering plants. In this work, the poisoning behaviors of PbO and PbCl2 on MC catalyst were explored, and their deactivation mechanisms were also clarified. Results indicated that PbCl2 presented more severe poisonousness than PbO. The addition of PbO obstructed favorable electron conversions between Mn and Ce atoms, consuming more oxygen vacancies and active oxygen species, consequently hindering the redox cycle. Apart from Pb poisoning effect, newly generated HCl over PbCl2-doped catalyst could preferentially adsorb on CeO2 to form inactive Cl− bonds and NH4Cl deposition, further limiting the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and reducing surface acid sites. Therefore, MC catalyst was deactivated more severely by the double poisoning cycles (Pb + HCl). This work paves a way for the development of high-performance Pb-tolerant low-temperature SCR catalyst, as well as Pb-deactivated catalyst regeneration technology.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation mechanisms of MnO x -CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag low-temperature SCR catalyst by PbO and PbCl2
